stream_context.summary: Kaze spends nearly the whole session trying to create a convincing “styrofoam” material for a new mountain stage, investigating how to fake bump-mapping and reflections on N64 hardware while keeping polygon count low.

development_findings.summary: The hack will feature 15 courses in total.
development_findings.quote: There’s going to be 15 courses in total.

development_findings.summary: Kaze wants the mountain surface built from a low-poly ‘styrofoam’ block, believing it will save polygons and add visual variety.
development_findings.quote: This mountain here … I think it would look better if it was made out of styrofoam and we could do this in less polygons.

development_findings.summary: Chosen approach: two textures—one base color, one highlight mask—whose blend is driven by view angle to fake bump-mapped reflection.
development_findings.quote: My idea for it is we have one texture that’s nearly white and a second texture that will be subtracted depending on the view angle so we can get some fake bump mapping.

development_findings.summary: Explored multiple texture-creation paths: sea-sponge photographs, stock photos, AI generation, hand-drawing, Blender displacement, and 3-D modelling bubbles.
Settled on pre-computing 8 normal-map variants (rotated) and updating the CI4 palette each frame; expects about 128 dot-products per frame, acceptable on N64.
development_findings.quote: Every extra one is a lot more data cost … but 128 vector multiplications should be relatively cheap.

development_findings.summary: Will limit styrofoam faces to specific rotations (≈6–8) so the palette trick remains feasible.
Vertex normals may need to be exported in a separate pass; Kaze weighs duplicating geometry vs. losing vertex colors.
Lilaa’s earlier optimisation idea (applied project-wide) saved ~30 instructions but produced “very cursed” code.
development_findings.quote: Your idea worked … it saved like 30 instructions … Unfortunately, that means we have very cursed code.

development_findings.summary: Breakthrough came when community member X-Links supplied a usable seamless styrofoam normal map; Kaze will implement shader logic next stream.
Alternative of true per-pixel lighting discarded because N64 cannot compute normals in real time; solution relies on palette manipulation instead.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is frustrated by chat asking off-topic questions; wishes to ‘just work on my game’.
context_findings.quote: I really don't want to talk about things — I want to just talk about making my game … I can’t do it anymore, man.

context_findings.summary: Admits steep learning curve with Blender materials and shaders, calling it ‘so goddamn annoying’.
context_findings.quote: Learning new tech is always so goddamn annoying.

context_findings.summary: Shows willingness to buy physical styrofoam and photograph it if digital methods fail, illustrating commitment.
context_findings.quote: Dude, I'm about to actually just buy styrofoam.

context_findings.summary: Ends stream after two hours of failed tests, fatigued but optimistic about new plan.
context_findings.quote: I did not think making styrofoam would turn into this much of a disaster.

key_stories.title: The Styrofoam Texture Odyssey
key_stories.summary: Kaze spends the entire stream hunting for a convincing styrofoam material. He cycles through stock photos, AI tools, Blender displacement, and even considers hand-painting before a community member provides a usable texture.
key_stories.challenge: Create a low-poly mountain surface that still looks like realistic styrofoam on N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Tried multiple texture sources, experimented with shader nodes and displacement in Blender, discussed palette-based bump-mapping trick, consulted chat for ideas.
key_stories.outcome: Adopts plan to pre-compute eight rotated normal maps and drive highlight intensity with vertex alpha; coding to begin next session, armed with X-Links’ texture.
key_stories.key_quote: We’re going to spend the entire stream working on styrofoam, aren’t we?

open_questions.context: Kaze outlined generating eight normal-map orientations and updating the palette each frame but did not detail memory footprint or exact implementation.
questions: How much ROM/RAM will the eight normal maps consume?
What is the exact routine for computing the 128 dot-products each frame?
Any fallbacks for hardware slow-down on real N64?
Could more than eight orientations be supported later?

open_questions.context: Styrofoam chosen mainly for tech reasons; no explanation of narrative or aesthetic relevance to Yoshi’s Island.
questions: Why styrofoam specifically for a mountain course in a Yoshi-centric game?
Is there a gameplay or story justification?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions Lilaa’s idea saved ~30 instructions but became ‘cursed code’, without details.
questions: Why did it require such unconventional code?
Any plans to refactor it later?
